div.head: The state of the world after the flood.
div.p:
We are now to direct our attention, to a
few of the principle events, which immed‐
iately followed the deluge. 20, of VIII, to end.
The very first intimation, which we have
of altars being built unto the Lord, is in
this passage, and we find, that it was
the very first action of Noah, after he came
out of the ark. But although this is the
very first positive intimation, which we
have, of altars being built unto the Lord
ithere is no ground to believe that the
descendants of Seth, built no altars. Nay
we have great reason to believe that al‐
tars were used, as we are told that they
offered sacrifices. We may infer, from
this, the first action of Noah, two things,
his gratitude, and his obedience. His grat‐
itude at once led him to build the altar,
his obedience to the previous ordinances
of God made him bring the animals to be
sacrificed thereon. He might well indeed
be grateful, for the merciful preservation
which had been extended to him. And we
thus find that Noahs very first action
symbolized the atonement of Christ.
We now find the acceptance of Noahs offe
ring announced to us. We are told. The
Lord smelled a sweet savour, and the Lord
said in his heart. I will not again
curse the ground any more for mans sake
for the imagination of mans heart is
evil continually. The reason here is re‐
markable[.] The heart of man is so
entirely evil from his youth, so utterly deprav
ed and corrupted, that no expression whate
ver of divine vengeance, would ever restrain
it, and it would be entirely useless continual
ly to destroy the race of mankind. But then
it may be objected, why did the flood come
at all[.] Why was this terrible judgement
executed against mankind, if it was not
to have the least effect upon them. It is
remarkable, that the same eventreason s
should be given, both for causing the flood
and afterwards witholding a repetition of
it. Now the deluge was not a trial of
men, to see whether any judgement or pun
ishment would have any effect in causing
their amendment, it was not an experim
ment of which God did not know the result
but it was to show, the utter hopelessness
of reclaiming the children of men, in any
other manner, than by their being born a
again in Christ. There was therefore good
reason, both for causing the deluge, and for
preventing its repetition. The next circum
stance which is to be noticed, is the grant
of animal food which God made to man
at this period. There was no grant be
fore made to man, of any thing for food
but the products of the vegetable kingdom
Still we have reason to suppose that animal
food was used before the flood, for all Gods
ordinances were utterly neglected and despised
by the sons of Cain[,] but we may infere,
from the grant now made of animal food,
that the sons of Seth, or at least, Noah, &
his family, abstained from it and held the
divine command in veneration. But, it may
be asked, why was that granted now, which
was denied before. It should be remembered
that the vegetable kingdom must have
been partially destroyed, or at least mater
ially injured, by the operation of the flood,
and for some time, vegetables must have
been entirely inadequate, for the sustenance
of mankind. Therefore the means of his sup
port are now enlarged, but at the same
time, all cruelty, which might have been
consequent upon the introduction of animal
food, was forbidden by the following precept
Verse 4.9. flesh with the life thereof which is
the blood thereof, shall ye not eat The next
circumstance to which our attention is to be
directed, is the enforcement of capital pun
ishment Whoso sheddeth mans blood, by man
shall his blood be shed, and the reason assig‐
ned, is the dignity of man, “for in the image
of Gode made he him, but this punishment
was entirely confided to murder. Some say
that this law, was confined to the economy
of Moses, but it is, I think, not so. It was
given as the law of the new world, and
was intended to go down to the latest
generations Noah is here the father of the
world, and this is the foundation of the
criminal law, throughout all the after‐
world. This severe law against murder was
rend{e}red necessary by the state of violence
which we are told prevailed before the
flood and in which it is probable that mur
der was no uncommon circumstance[,] and
no ordinance atall less severe than the one
under consideration, would have had the
least effect in its prevention.

We now pass on, to the token which is
given by God, of the faithfulness of the
covenant which he made, not to des‐
troy mankind again. It has been said
that as physical nature is such, as, with
out the intervention of any miracle, to
produce the rainbow, by the refraction of
the suns rays in the drops of falling rain,
the bow must either not have been a to‐
ken to mankind, given at this time, or
else, that there could have been no
rain upon the earth before the flood.
For this last hypothesis, we have, on the
contrary, ample reason to believe that
there was rain. 5 and 6[,] of II But there
went up a mist from the earth and wa
tered the whole face of the ground, for
the Lord had not yet caused it to rain
upon the earth from which we may in
fer, that rain followed immediately[,] &
for the first, this is no proof that the
rainbow was not a token given by God,
We should rather say that God selected an
object well known, and of frequent recur‐
rence in the common course of nature
as a token which would constantly be in
view, of the faithfulness of his covenant[,] &
which was quite sufficient. After this,
we find the whole human race, having
collected themselves into one community[,] a
bout to enter into a scheme of pride and
wickedness, which clearly shows how soon
the depravity incident to man had ag
ain taken root among the progeny of
Noah. This is the first public step of
any consequence in which they general
ly concurred; and this is one, which di
rectly sets forth their spirit of pride
We read, that they found a plain in
the land of Shinar, and they said [one] to
another, Go to, let us build a city and
tower whose top may reach unto heaven
and they had brick for stone, and slime
had they for mortar. Now, this tower
was certainly not built for the purpose
of affording them an asylum from a
second deluge, which they might have
supposed to be impending, for we read
that the tower was built in a plain, &
it is certain, that the very highest e‐
minences would have been selected for
its foundation, had it been intended for
this purpose, for no tower that they
could build, would ever have attained
the elevation of the circumjacent moun
tains, and again, it could not be to
prevent their threatenʼd dispersion through
the earth, for that was inevitable, as
such numbers could never dwell togeth
er, as well on the account of scarcity of
food, as for various other causes. No, it
was to make them a name, to raise
a mon[u]ment to themselves, before their
necessary dispersion. They built no al
tars to their God, to testify their
gratitude to him, they brought no sac
rifices, to testify their expectation of the
coming of a Saviour. No— every motive,
was lost in one which was pride, and that
in its most extravagant form. They a{p}
pear to have forgotten the existence of a
God, and th[is] was a mere monument
to themselves, which they intended to
make them a name, that is, to per
petuate their memory and fame to the
latest posterity showing how far sin,
had, at this period, again found its
way among men. But this undertak
ing, which was begun to perpetuate their
fame, did only in the end perpetuate thier
shame for God caused it to be given up, and
their dispersion was effected so much the soon
er, and in order to effect it the more com
pletely, GOD caused the confusion of tongues,
which, besides scattering them abroad in
to all countries, was in itself a severe
punishment, and remains so to the pres
ent day. For, even now, infinite evil and
difficulty arises from the variety of langua
ges spoken in different parts of the globe[.]
Much time is wasted, and much talent
is lost or dissipated by many students, be
fore this unavoidable difficulty can be
overcome[.] And if we consider, what the
time thus wasted, and the talent thus
lost, might have effected, had they been
applied to any useful or beneficial purpose,
we cannot but acknowledge, that the con
fusion of tongues, was, and is, a very se
vere punishment.

Yet, as we uniformly find it, this judgment
is mingled with mercy. Supposing,
that the children of men had concluded
their impious undertaking, and had built
their city, and their tower. The necessity
that they should separate, would, very
soon, have become pressing[.] And would
not dreadful contests have taken place
among a multitude so hardened, &
who had entirely forgotten, or despised
the commandments and ordinances of God{'s}
contests, as to who should quit the part,
the very small part, of the world already
known, and go out among the bri
ars, and thorns of the wilderness, far
from all inhabited, or cultivated reg‐{ions}
to build themselves new cities, or find new
pastures[.] There would have been such com
bats for the regions already known, as would
almost have exterminated the race of man
as effectually as did the deluge[.] All this
violence and bloodshed however, is preven
ted by the confusion of tongues, which scat
tered them at once, saving them and pun
ishing them at the same time[.]

In spite of this however, we find, after
their dispersion, the viol{e}nce which preceded
the flood again commencing[.] It is said
that Nimrod was a mighty hunter before
the Lord. Now at this period, when ani‐
mals multiplied more than men, it became
of very great consequence, that the more
powerful of them, at least, should be des
troyed. In consequence, he who excelled in
this department would obtain a leadership
and authority over his fellow, which after‐
wards readily he turned to his own aggran
dizement. The hunting of Nimrod, is, on
this account, celibrated, and we can have
no doubt, that he afterwards took advan
tage of this the authority[,] thus obtained,
to raise himself to the power and dignity
of a monarch, or a tyrant. I am not speak
ing just now against monarchy That is
an institution which I consider to have been
ordained by God, and which therefore should
be honoured by men, and only evil in its
origin. Again[,] it may be supposed, that
any individual, who, after the dispersion, first
led to the building of towns, or the establish
ment of Colonies, would in the first case,
be looked up to with respect, or even vene‐
ration, which would increase, until, after
his death, he might be ranked as a minor
divinity[.] The number of these divinities would
be gradually increased, and their actions
would, in the course of time, be exaggera
ted by tradition, till the true, and only God
would be entirely lost, and this was the o
rigin of idolatry. This was the state of
abandonment, and idolatry into which the
earth was plunged, at the period of the cal
ling of Noah Abraham

We shall now proceed to draw a few in
ferences, from the circumstances, which
we have seen to day to have been those
of the world immediately after the flood
I would first notice the desperate and in
curable wickedness of the human heart; I
have often spoken of this before, and I speak
of it again, both because examples of is
are constantly introduced throughout the
whole of the sacred writings, and because it
is a circumstance which can
not be too often impressed on the mind of
every one. We see, that as soon as any
individual made himself useful to his fel
low creatures in any one department he
employed those powers which he had thus
obtained, to aggrandize himself, in short
to subjugate, and tyrannize over that
people, for whose benefit he had previous
ly been labouring. Again, does not
the entire absence of religion, from the
multitude in the plain of Shinar, offer
another remarkable example, of this dread
ful depravity[.] Every thing was lost in
their selfish ness, in their vain glory; in
their pride; God was altogether forgotten
and mankind gave a loose rein to their
passions, ending in their own confusion.

Again, we should learn from this, the
amazing importance of humility. The fame
of the builders of Babel, has, through their
pride, been perpetuated, but not in the
manner that they wished, to their glory
and their honour, but to their abasement
and degradation. Had they been found
worshipping God with humility, had they
built altars, and brought sacrifices, it
had then been an everlasting monument
to their glory, and posterity would have
looked back upon their humility, with res
peck, and veneration. But it was not
so, and their confusion is now an everl‐
lasting memorial of that truth, that pride
cometh before a fall, and of the impor‐
tance, the momentous importance, of our
which I would endeavour to impress upon
the minds of all present, of the one of the
very first of the graces, simplicit hum
ility[,] which christain grace can only be
obtained, and preserved, by going to the cross
of Christ, and there, when we find the Redeem
er laying down his life, because man was found
so fearfully and astonishingly depraved, that
nothing else would save him, we shall no long
er trust, in our powers to obtain salvation
through our own righteousness, and shall dis
cover, and acknowledge, that we have noth
ing whatsoever, whereof to glory&—
